'Copy-number variations' ('CNV's)âa form of structural variationâare alterations
of the DNA of a genome that results in the cell having an abnormal number of
copies of one or more sections of the DNA. CNVs correspond to relatively large
regions of the genome that have been deleted (fewer than the normal number) or
duplicated (more than the normal number) on certain chromosomes. For example,
the chromosome that normally has sections in order as A-B-C-D might
instead have sections A-B-C-C-D (a duplication of "C") or A-B-
D (a deletion of "C").

This variation accounts for roughly 12% of human genomic DNA and each variation
may range from about one kilobase (1,000 nucleotide bases) to several megabases
in size. CNVs contrast with single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),
which affect only one single nucleotide base.
